entries: A defining part of the Forgotten Prince's story is that he himself has been forgotten. Should a character somehow learn the true name of the Forgotten Prince during their adventures, they have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells that he casts.

entries.name: The Forgotten Prince's Lair
entries: The Prince dwells in the Castle of Forgotten Things in Thelanis. The castle seems to be its own distinct layer of Thelanis; if it exists in some other realm, its location has been forgotten. There are no doors that allow exit from the castle, and all the windows are sealed and show scenes of places that have been forgotten. The only way to enter or leave the castle is through magic, whether by spell, through a manifest zone, or through a portal. Such portals can take many forms, such as the sack described in the legend above; normal people forget the location of a portal within an hour of discovering it, though player characters and other remarkable people could be immune to this effect. It's possible characters could discover that what they assumed to be a normal {@item Bag of Holding|XDMG} can serve as a portal to the Castle of Lost Things.

monsterFluff.name: Valaara
entries: Valaara is known as the Crawling Queen, the Watcher in the Walls, and the Keeper of Worms. It's said that you can hear Valaara's voice in the rustling of roaches and the keening of locusts. In some tales, Valaara crafts worms that crawl through the ear and consume a creature's brain; in others, when its maggots devour a corpse, Valaara can recreate the victim in its Deepest Hive. No one knows what Valaara wants, but its minions could be all around you even now, crawling in your walls and moving beneath your feet.

entries.name: Chitin Consciousness
entries: Valaara embodies the alien nature of insects in all aspects. Valaara's symbionts may be formed from chitin, but it also has creations like the Spellburrow and the Throwing Scarab (detailed in chapter 7 )—insects that burrow into the skin of the bearer. Those touched by Valaara may undergo a physical metamorphosis and manifest insect traits, but Valaara's touch can also transform the mind. Some who hear the whispers of the Crawling Queen become fascinated by insects, while others suffer more dramatic transformations. Valaara's most persistent cults spread by forming a hive; one creature becomes the queen, and others touched by this cultist find their original personality and desires fading, consumed by the need to fulfill their purpose in the hive. Usually this effect is limited, a psychic connection that only binds a few people; but in a few cases, this psychic contagion has been virulent and contagious, consuming entire towns.

entries.name: Valaara's Minions
entries: The cults of the Crawling Queen are described in detail in chapter 3. Valaara doesn't use dolgaunts or dolgrims; rather, it often transforms humanoids into insect forms. These creatures use the statistics of Thri-kreen, Driders, or Umber Hulks, but their appearance can vary dramatically; a group of servitors could be roach-people as opposed to the typical mantis form of the thri-kreen. In other places it works through consuming worms, producing creatures with the statistics of Spawn of Kyuss. In general, Valaara may employ any sort of creature thematically related to insects or worms, from simple swarms and Giant Spiders to Carrion Crawlers, Ankhegs, Remorhazes, or even Purple Worms. But these monsters should be seen as a starting point. Like all daelkyr, Valaara is constantly experimenting and creating new things. Imagine a purple worm with malign intelligence and psychic powers, or teleporting ankhegs that burrow through the fabric of space.

entries.name: Valaara's Lair
entries: Like other daelkyr, Valaara is bound within a demiplane in Khyber. However, Valaara has bred burrowing worms that chew through the fabric of reality, carving a web of passages between her Deepest Hive and the world above. An organization that discovers the upper layers of these tunnels could use them to move swiftly across the world, entering a tunnel in the Lhazaar Principalities, traveling five miles, and emerging in Sarlona or the Eldeen Reaches. Smugglers or explorers might make use of this wonder, never knowing what lies in the deeper tunnels—until Valaara's minions seize them, or until they are consumed by the psychic influence of the Crawling Queen. While tunnels to the Deepest Hive can appear anywhere that suits the story, they are also less permanent than the ties between Eberron and the realms of many other daelkyr. A tunnel to the Deepest Hive can appear wherever it suits the needs of a story, but it's also possible to collapse a passage and break a connection.

The upper tunnels of Valaara's realm are usually formed of fused glass-like material, then as explorers delve deeper, they find the walls formed of chitin and muscle, with insects swarming across every surface. One might discover pulsing cocoons, nests of slumbering purple worms, or chambers lined with thousands of glowing eggs. And in the heart is the Deepest Hive itself, where Valaara weaves its webs and conducts its sinister experiments.
Tunnels to the Deepest Hive can appear anywhere. A region containing a passage to the Deepest Hive can be warped in one or more of these ways:

entries.name: Creeping Thoughts
entries: The area within 1 mile of the passage is infested with swarms of harmless insects. Whenever a creature other than Valaara or one of its allies finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} in that area, that creature must succeed on a DC 22 Wisdom saving throw or suffer from temporary delusions (see "Delusions of Valaara" below).

entries.name: Swarming Tyrant
entries: Beasts that live within a mile of the passage undergo physical transformation, developing insect characteristics such as compound eyes, extra limbs, chitinous plating, and hive behavior. Valaara exerts its dominance over animals in its domain. All Beasts within 1 mile of the passage have the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition while in that area.

These regional effects build over time. If a passage has just appeared, there may be a slight increase in insect activity and the saving throw on the Delusions effect will be much lower. The longer the passage remains, the more notable the effects become. If Valaara dies or if the passage is destroyed, the effects fade away after {@dice 1d10} days.

entries.name: Delusions of Valaara
entries: If a creature falls prey to Valaara's influence, it suffers temporary delusions. Roll on the Delusions of Valaara table to determine the nature of this effect, which takes the form of a curse that lasts until the creature is targeted by a {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} spell or similar magic.

entries.caption: Delusions of Valaara
rows: "There are worms crawling through my flesh."
"I hear secrets in the buzzing of insects."
"I am undergoing a metamorphosis into a glorious insect form."
"I have a psychic connection to one or more people."
"I must serve my hive and protect my queen."
"I am an insect that's evolved into humanoid form."

spell.name: Aundair's Silent Sanctum
entries: You surround yourself with an invisible bubble of energy in a 5-foot {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}. The sphere muffles sound in both directions. Creatures outside of the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks made to hear any sounds from within the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}, and creatures inside the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation} have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks made to hear sounds outside of the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}.

In addition, creatures have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against effects that require them to hear a sound from the other side of the {@variantrule Emanation [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Emanation}, such as the {@spell Command|XPHB} spell.

spell.name: Concussive Burst
entries: A pulse of energy ripples through the air at a point you choose within range, dealing minor damage over a wide area. Each creature within a 20-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} centered on that point makes a Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 2d4} Force damage on a failed save and has the {@condition Deafened|XPHB} condition until the end of your next turn. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage only.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Using a Higher-Level Spell Slot
entries: The damage increases by {@dice 2d4} for each spell slot level above 1.

spell.name: Force Blast
entries: You unleash a bolt of mystical power at a creature or an object within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} Force damage.

entriesHigherLevel.name: Cantrip Upgrade
entries: This damage increases by {@dice 1d8} when you reach levels 5 ({@dice 2d8}), 11 ({@dice 3d8}), and 17 ({@dice 4d8}).

spell.name: Magecraft

components.m: a set of Artisan's Tools or a Herbalism Kit

entries: You channel your arcane talent through a set of tools. Choose an {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB|Artisan Tool} or {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}. Until the spell ends, you add {@dice 1d6} to ability checks you make when you take the {@action Utilize|XPHB} action with the chosen tool.

items.name: Fernian Resistance
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Fire damage and Necrotic damage.

items.name: Flame Bearer
entries: You know the {@spell Produce Flame|XPHB} cantrip. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose the ability when you select this species).

items.name: Celestial Revelation
entries: When you reach character level 3, you can transform as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} using one of the options below (choose the option each time you transform). The transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it (no action required). Once you transform, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Once on each of your turns before the transformation ends, you can deal extra damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra damage equals your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and the extra damage's type is either Necrotic for Necrotic Shroud or Radiant for Heavenly Wings and Inner Darkness.
Here are the transformation options:

items.name: Heavenly Wings
entries: Two spectral wings sprout from your back temporarily. Until the transformation ends, you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

items.name: Inner Darkness
entries: You consume light and life, creating a shroud of shadows. For the duration, you reduce {@variantrule Bright Light|XPHB} in a 20-foot radius to {@variantrule Dim Light|XPHB}, and at the end of each of your turns, each creature within 10 feet of you takes Necrotic damage equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}.

items.name: Necrotic Shroud
entries: Your eyes briefly become pools of darkness, and flightless wings sprout from your back temporarily. Creatures other than your allies within 10 feet of you must succeed on a Charisma saving throw ({@dc 8} plus your Charisma modifier and {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}) or have the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition until the end of your next turn.

items.name: Herald of Death
entries: You know the {@spell Toll The Dead|XPHB} cantrip. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose the ability when you select this species).

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-6 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Discipline
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Strength in Unity
entries: If you fail a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can gain a bonus to the roll equal to the number of allies you can see within 30 feet of you (maximum bonus of +5). Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: War and Peace
entries: You gain proficiency in two of the following skills: {@skill Athletics|XPHB}, {@skill History|XPHB}, {@skill Intimidation|XPHB}, {@skill Performance|XPHB}.

Dhakaani hobgoblins are known as ghaal'dar, "mighty folk"—not to be confused with the Ghaal'dar tribes that dominate Darguun. The ghaal'dar are soldiers, scholars, and leaders, valued for their versatility and their vision.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small (about 3-4 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Discipline
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Naturally Stealthy
entries: You can take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action even when you are obscured only by a creature that is at least one size larger than you.

entries.name: Nimbleness
entries: You can move through the space of any creature that is a size larger than you, but you can't stop in the same space.

Dhakaani goblins are known as golin'dar, "quick folk." They reproduce and mature faster than other dar, and form the bulk of the labor force in Dhakaani society. This includes menial labor, agriculture, food preparation, and skilled craftwork. Though ghaal'dar are the primary smiths of weapons and armor, most other manufacturing is done by the golin'dar. While this work may be less dramatic than the martial paths of the ghaal'dar and guul'dar, it's vital to survival and the golin'dar are respected for their contributions. Other golin'dar take a different path, that of the Khesh'dar, the Silent Folk who live in the shadows of the empire.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 6-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Brave
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition.

entries.name: Long-Limbed
entries: When you make a melee attack on your turn, your reach for it is 5 feet greater than normal.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on any ability check you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XPHB} condition. You also count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity.

entries.name: Stand by the Strong
entries: When an ally within 30 feet that can see you fails a saving throw to avoid or end the {@condition Frightened|XPHB} condition, you can use your {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to allow them to reroll the saving throw.

Dhakaani bugbears are known as guul'dar, "strong folk," and are celebrated for their strength and courage. They help perform heavy labor where strength is required, but most yearn to prove their mettle on the battlefield, risking their lives to earn the glory known as atcha.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 7-8 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Your teeth are natural weapons, which you can use to make {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB|Unarmed Strikes}. If you hit with them, you deal Piercing damage equal to {@dice 1d6} plus your Strength modifier in place of the normal Bludgeoning damage of your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}.

entries.name: Hunter's Senses
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Perception|XPHB}, {@skill Stealth|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Rampage
entries: When you use your Bite or reduce a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} with an attack, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to move up to half your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} and make one attack with a weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} using your Bite.

Fierce and feral, the first gnolls were hyenas infused with malefic power by archfiends of war and the wild. They were created as cruel soldiers to serve in the endless conflicts of fiends, but over the course of countless generations a number of gnoll clans broke their ties to their demon overlords. These free gnolls are fiercely loyal to their pack and their clan, and serve as a stabilizing force within Droaam.

Gnolls that are bound to the overlords are vicious and wild. Those who have escaped this bondage still have a fiendish spark within, but they contain and control this power. Some learn to wield it as Warlocks. Others known as hwyri train to fight demons and other supernatural threats. Even free gnolls can be aggressive, but they are gifted hunters and fiercely loyal to those they choose as family.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Relentless Endurance
entries: When you are reduced to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} but not killed outright, you can drop to 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} instead. Once you use this trait, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Versatile
entries: You gain an {@filter Origin feat|feats|category=o} of your choice.

Long ago, the orcs of the Shadow Marches welcomed human refugees from Sarlona. The two species have lived together in harmony for centuries. Most humans or orcs from the Marches have some degree of mixed lineage, even though they may use the game statistics of the species they outwardly resemble. However, the union of human and orc can produce children who have physical traits of both parent species. In the Shadow Marches, such people are called Jhorgun'taal, "children of two bloods"; they are celebrated as a symbol of the bond between orcs and humans. Jhorgun'taal blend the endurance of their orc ancestors with the flexibility of humanity.

As House Tharashk has spread across Khorvaire, Jhorgun'taal are often found as inquisitives, bounty hunters, and prospectors. The Mark of Finding can manifest on humans, orcs, or Jhorgun'taal who can trace their ancestry to the Shadow Marches.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4-7 feet tall) or Small (about 2-4 feet tall), chosen when you select this species

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 120 feet.

entries.name: Personal Symbiont
entries: You are bound to an alien entity that is part of your body and can't be removed. Your symbiont possesses a minor supernatural ability, which it can use on your behalf. Choose a cantrip from the following list: {@spell Acid Splash|XPHB}, {@spell Guidance|XPHB} (self only), {@spell Light|XPHB}, {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB}, {@spell Mind Slive|XPHB}, {@spell Poison Spray|XPHB}, {@spell Resistance|XPHB} (self only), {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB}, {@spell Thorn Whip|XPHB}. You can switch to a different cantrip from this list whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for the spells you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select this species).

entries.name: Symbiont Mastery
entries: You can attune to one magic item that has the Symbiotic Nature property without it counting toward the maximum number of magic items you can attune to. In addition, whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you can end your {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} to a magic item that has the Symbiotic Nature property. When doing so, you can ignore any restrictions that require you be targeted by a {@spell Remove Curse|XPHB} spell or similar magic before the symbiont can be removed.

entries.name: Unnatural Resilience
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Poison damage. You also have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition Poisoned|XPHB} condition.

entries.caption: Ruinbound Mutations
rows: {@b Unnatural Hair.} Is your hair an unusual color? Ectoplasmic in nature? Does it move of its own accord?
{@b Unusual Skin.} Is your skin transparent? Slick? An unnatural color?
{@b Aberrant Eyes.} Are your eyes luminous? Invisible? Do they resemble the eyes of an animal, or are they seemingly absent?
{@b Strange Appetites.} Do you prefer your food charred? Do you eat flowers, or can you only eat living things?

{@b Living Tattoos.} You appear to have exotic tattoos across your body. They slowly and constantly change, and you have no control over the design. Do they show images or words, or are they incomprehensible?

{@b Ageless.} The passage of time affects your appearance differently than others. Do you appear old beyond your years, or look surprisingly young no matter your age? As you grow older, do you look younger?
{@b Inexplicable Hearing.} You have no visible ears, yet you can hear clearly. Does sound feel different to you? How do you experience it?
{@b Extra Joints.} You have one or more extra joints. Is it just an unusual joint in your fingers, or can you bend your entire leg backward?

entries: The Ruinbound are mutants that can be born to any humanoid species that has contact with the Daelkyr or their minions. A Ruinbound is born with a personal symbiont—an unnatural entity bound to the child. Unlike most symbionts, this entity cannot be separated from its host, and the two are permanently fused. Many Ruinbound have additional disturbing mutations; you can roll on the Ruinbound Mutations table for ideas, or create your own. These secondary mutations are disturbing, but they don't change the rules of how that character is played or grant mechanical benefits. For example, even if a Ruinbound seems to have no eyes, their vision uncannily works as well as any other member of their species, though it defies logic.

Aside from their mutations, Ruinbound share the appearance of their parent species. The Mror Holds have seen a surge of Ruinbound births since the War Below began, and there have always been Ruinbound orcs and humans in the Shadow Marches. Even in these places, however, the Ruinbound are rare and remarkable, and generally don't pass their traits on to their offspring. More information about the Ruinbound can be found in the Mror Holds section of Uncharted Domains.

When making a Ruinbound character, work with your DM to determine the appearance of your Personal Symbiont. It is organic and clearly alien, and when you cast a cantrip with this trait, it should be obvious that the symbiont is the source. A symbiont that casts {@spell Mage Hand|XPHB} could be a thin tentacle or an ectoplasmic insect that emerges from your body and performs the action. An eyestalk protruding from your shoulder could grant you Guidance as it studies the situation and telepathically advises you—or it might blast your enemies with a {@spell Mind Sliver|XPHB}.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 120 feet.

entries.name: Swift Swimmer
entries: You have a Swim speed equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

entries.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: As a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, you can enter a blood frenzy for 1 minute. During this time, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

You can use this {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Natural Armor
entries: You have tough, scaly skin. When you aren't wearing any armor, your base {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} equals 12 plus your Dexterity modifier. You can use a {@item Shield|XPHB} and still gain this benefit.

entries.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: You can breathe air and underwater, but you need to be submerged at least once every 4 hours to avoid suffocating.

The sahuagin are an ancient species spawned in the ocean depths. With their armored skin and fearsome demeanor, they have long inspired terror in the people of the surface world. They are natural predators with aggressive instincts, kin to the shark and often devotees of the Devourer. But there is nothing innately evil about most sahuagin; in the depths of the Thunder Sea, sahuagin champions battle fiends and aberrations.

Sahuagin are amphibious humanoids with leathery skin, sharp teeth, and webbed hands and feet. They have finlike crests on their heads, which extend and retract in response to their mood. While the majority of sahuagin have gray-green scales, others have scales with dramatic, colorful patterns.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe air and water.

entries.name: Blessing of the Sea
entries: You have two forms: your natural merfolk form and that of a landwalker. As a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, you can shape-shift to change from your merfolk form to your landwalker form. While in your landwalker form, your fish-like fluke splits into 2 legs. Your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} increases by 20 feet, but your {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} is reduced to 0.
You stay in the new form until you take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to revert to your merfolk form.

entries.name: Karakala Lore
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Nature|XPHB}, {@skill Performance|XPHB}, or {@skill Survival|XPHB} skill.

The Kalamer merfolk dwell in the Thunder Sea, and most spend their entire lives beneath the waves. However, a few are called to walk above the water. Those that embrace this path may become Kalamer Landwalkers, gaining the magical ability to transform their fish-tail into a pair of humanoid legs. Landwalkers are exceptionally rare, and few surface-dwellers have ever seen one. Some Kalamer Landwalkers feel a call to accomplish a specific goal, fulfilling a mission for the good of the world. Others are driven purely by curiosity, and yearn to see new places and find wondrous things.

raceFluff.name: Aasimar (Fernian)
entries: If your Aasimar's powers flow from Fernia, you are infused with otherworldly fire.

raceFluff.name: Aasimar (Mabaran)
entries: If your Aasimar's powers are drawn from Mabar, you are bound to shadows and despair.

feat.name: Aereni Expertise
entries: Growing up in Aerenal, you spent decades developing your talent with one particular skill. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Skill Proficiency
entries: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice.

entries.name: Expertise
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} with the skill you selected for this feat.

feat.name: Aquatic Adaptation
entries: You are able to live underwater. This may be a natural feature of your character if you're playing a Malenti or an Elf from Valraea, or it could be the result of arcane transmutation or a divine blessing. Whatever the origin of this gift, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe underwater. If you possess the Limited Amphibiousness trait in addition to this feat, this eliminates your dependence on water.

entries.name: Athletic Build
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Athletics|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Natural Swimmer
entries: You have a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

feat.name: Envoy Specialist
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Envoy Competence
entries: You gain proficiency with one tool of your choice.

entries.name: Integrated Tool
entries: Choose one tool you are proficient with. You have a working model of this tool integrated into your body, which can't be removed. As long as you have a hand free, you can make use of the integrated tool.

entries.name: Innate Talent
entries: When you make an ability check with the integrated tool, you can roll {@dice 1d4} and add the number rolled to the ability check.

feat.name: Khesh'dar Training
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Swift and Silent
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Master of Shadows
entries: You gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} with the {@skill Stealth|XPHB} skill.

entries.name: Fade Away
entries: When you take the {@action Hide|XPHB} action, the DC for a successful check is reduced to 10. All other restrictions still apply.

feat.name: Focused Personas
entries: You've developed personas that help you focus your talents. Work with your DM to define two unique personas—identities with distinct appearances and personalities. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Adept Persona
entries: Choose a tool and define a persona associated with it. Whenever you use your Shape-Shifter trait to assume the persona, you gain proficiency with the chosen tool and when you make an ability check with the chosen tool, you can roll {@dice 1d4} and add the number rolled to the ability check.

entries.name: Expert Persona
entries: Choose a skill you are proficient in and define a different persona associated with it. Whenever you use your Shape-Shifter trait to assume the persona, you gain {@variantrule Expertise|XPHB} in the chosen skill.

entries.name: Skin Cant
entries: You are fluent in {@language Skin Cant|ExploringEberron24}, a language used by the Changeling Travelers.

feat.name: Thoughtsinger
entries: You have honed your telepathic abilities, allowing you to link to and guide your companions as a united group. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Superior Telepathy
entries: The telepathy granted by your Mind Link trait has a range of 120 feet or 10 times your level, whichever is higher.

entries.name: Thoughtsong
entries: When you use your Mind Link trait to grant a creature the ability to speak to you telepathically, you form a mental connection with that individual. When you communicate telepathically, you may choose to send the message to all creatures you currently have a mental connection to. You may also allow those creatures to speak telepathically with one another. These effects last for as long as the Mind Link remains in effect.

entries.name: Telepathic Aid
entries: If you can speak telepathically to an ally using your Mind Link trait, you can take the {@action Help|XPHB} action to aid them in attacking a creature, even if you are more than 5 feet away from them.

feat.name: Uul Dhakaan
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Dreamwalker
entries: You remain fully lucid when you dream and when you wake, you clearly remember everything that transpired.

entries.name: Mentor in the Uul
entries: There is a spirit in the Uul Dhakaan that serves as your mentor. Work with your DM to develop the identity of this spirit; they could be the memory of an ancestor or fallen hero, or a living uul'kala bard. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, there's a chance you'll receive a vision, a mission, or a clue about your current situation.

entries.name: Shielded by Dreams
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

feat.name: Aereni Half-Life
entries: You've undergone rituals that bind you to Irian and the Undying Court. Many who undergo this process have a desiccated appearance, similar to a mummy; it's up to you to decide whether you are affected in this way. Regardless of your appearance, you gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Deathless
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB|Death Saving Throws}.

entries.name: Resistance
entries: You have {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Necrotic damage and Radiant damage.

entries.name: Radiant Focus
entries: If you cast a spell that deals Necrotic damage, you can choose to have it inflict Radiant damage instead.

feat.name: Changeling Metamorphosis
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Hardened Skin
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}.

entries.name: Metamorphosis
entries: When you use your Shape-Shifter trait, you may choose one of the following options. You gain the benefits of the chosen option until you use your Shape-Shifter trait again.

entries.name: Aquatic Adaptation
entries: You sprout gills and grow webs between your fingers. You can breathe underwater and gain a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@spell Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Natural Weapons
entries: You grow claws (Slashing), fangs (Piercing), horns (Piercing), or hooves (Bludgeoning). When you use your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB} to deal damage with that new growth, it deals {@damage 1d6} damage of the type in parentheses instead of dealing the normal damage for your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XPHB}, and you can choose to use your Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls rather than using Strength.

feat.name: Juggernaut Plating
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Resilient Armor
entries: While you remain alive, armor you have donned can't be targeted by any effect (such as the {@spell Heat Metal|XPHB} spell or the antennae of a rust monster) against your will.

entries.name: Adamantine Body
entries: Any {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB} against you becomes a normal hit.

feat.name: Superior Shifting
entries: You have a potent connection to the beast within, strengthening your body and your ability to shift. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Shifting Endurance
entries: At the start of your turn, you can use your Shifting trait (no action required). The transformation now lasts 10 minutes.

entries.name: Shifter Recovery
entries: You can use your Shifting trait one additional time. You regain 1 expended use when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}, and all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

feat.name: Quori Bond
entries: You possess a particularly strong bond with your quori spirit. You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Quori Lineage
entries: Choose a lineage from the Quori Lineages table. Your choice affects the Skill and Spell sections detailed below.
{@i * when cast using this feat, {@spell Shatter|XPHB} deals Psychic damage}

entries.name: Skill
entries: When you make an ability check with the skill associated with your quori lineage, you can roll {@dice 1d4} and add the number rolled to the ability check.

entries.name: Spell
entries: You always have the spell associated with your quori lineage prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level. Your spellcasting ability for the spell is the ability increased by this feat.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) 2 {@item Dagger|XPHB|Daggers}, {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Bedroll|XPHB}, 2 {@item Pouch|XPHB|Pouches}, Shiftweave clothing, 10 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You're an urban nomad wandering from city to city. You spent your childhood traveling with your family, using your abilities to evade your enemies. Do you strive to be a force for positive change in the world, or are you an opportunist looking out for yourself? Most Changeling Travelers are Changelings. If you're not a Changeling, you were born to a changeling parent and traveled with them; you could use a Disguise Kit or illusion magic to mimic their abilities.

a.special: The equipment of a background related to the person you consumed

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: Choose {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}, or {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) The equipment of a background related to the person you consumed; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You were born a sahuagin in the Eternal Dominion of the Thunder Sea, but ritual magic and the blood of the kar'lassa allowed you to consume and replace a surface dweller. You can never regain your original form; for all intents and purposes, you are who you appear to be. You're physically indistinguishable from them, and you have enough of their memories to fool even their family and friends. But you have the mind of a sahuagin, and you're loyal to the Dominion.

As a Malenti, the first question is why the Dominion chose to replace this particular person, and how your mission relates to your activities as an adventurer. It's possible that your only mission is to observe the dryskins and occasionally provide information to a sahuagin spymaster, or you might have a specific goal that drives your actions during your adventures.

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one kind of {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Artisan's Tools|XPHB} (same as above), 2 {@item Pouch|XPHB|Pouches}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 32 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You worked your way up in House Cannith or the Arcane Congress, studying at a trade school and working in an industrial forgehold. While you've abandoned the factory in favor of adventure, you still have strong ties in the Fabricator's Guild.

items.name: Tool Proficiency:
items.entry: Choose one kind of {@item Gaming Set|XPHB}

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Spear|XPHB}, {@item Shortbow|XPHB}, {@item Arrow|XPHB|20 Arrows}, {@item Gaming Set|XPHB} (same as above), {@item Healer's Kit|XPHB}, {@item Quiver|XPHB}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 14 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You operated and maintained the engines of war. What nation did you serve? Are you proud of your service, or haunted by your deeds? Did you serve and retire with distinctionor are you a folk hero who deserted to help innocents?

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Quarterstaff|XPHB}, {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB} (history), {@item Parchment|XPHB} (8 sheets), {@item Robe|XPHB}, 8 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You don't do well with authority. You may have started with Arcanix or the Twelve, but you were thrown out after challenging the system one too many times. You're brilliantbut determined to find your own path.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB|2 Daggers}, {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Gaming Set|XPHB} (any), {@item Bedroll|XPHB}, {@item Pouch|XPHB|2 Pouches}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 16 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You've never studied arcane science, but you have an intuitive talent for artifice. Perhaps you grew up on battlefields, scavenging parts from warforged titans or shattered floating fortresses. Your work isn't pretty—and often seems like it shouldn't work—yet you can do things no magewright can match.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Choose A or B: (A) {@item Dagger|XPHB|2 Daggers}, {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, {@item Crowbar|XPHB}, {@item Pouch|XPHB|2 Pouches}, {@item Traveler's Clothes|XPHB}, 16 GP; or (B) 50 GP

entries: You provided arcane assistance to an organization operating out of the public eye. Did you serve with the Royal Eyes of Aundair or the King's Citadel of Breland, crafting Common items for agents? Or was it a shadier operation like the Boromar Clan or House Tarkanan? Why did you shift to a life of adventure? What pieces of your old life could come back to haunt you?

This magic weapon has 5 charges. When you hit a creature with it, you can expend 1 of the weapon's charges to negate all of the creature's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} to damage until the end of your next turn. The weapon regains {@dice 1d4 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn.

This magic weapon grants a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it. When you are hidden from a creature and miss it with a Ranged weapon attack made with this weapon, making the attack doesn't reveal your position.

inherits.reqAttune: by a Character Proficient with the Tool
entries: While using this tool as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you gain a +1 bonus to spell attack rolls. In addition, you can add this bonus to any ability check you make using this tool.

inherits.reqAttune: by a Character Proficient with the Tool
entries: While using this tool as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you gain a +2 bonus to spell attack rolls. In addition, you can add this bonus to any ability check you make using this tool.

inherits.reqAttune: by a Character Proficient with the Tool
entries: While using this tool as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you gain a +3 bonus to spell attack rolls. In addition, you can add this bonus to any ability check you make using this tool.

This magic weapon grants a {=bonusWeapon} bonus to attack and damage rolls made with it. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, choose one of the following creature types: Aberration, Beast, Celestial, Dragon, Fiend, Giant, or Undead.

The weapon has 4 charges. If you hit a creature of the chosen type with the weapon, you can expend 1 charge and inflict an additional {@damage 2d6} damage of the weapon's type with the attack. The weapon regains {@dice 1d4} expended charges daily at dawn.

A creation of the daelkyr, this weapon is formed from muscle and bone. It may moan, growl, or wail, and it twists in your grip if it doesn't like you. If any creature attempts to wield this weapon while not attuned to it, it has {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on attack rolls made using the weapon. Additionally, if you are attuned to this weapon when another creature tries to wield it, the weapon's hilt extrudes sharp thorns and that creature takes {@damage 1d4} Piercing damage each turn.

While attuned to and wielding this weapon, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to bond to it, causing tendrils from the hilt of the weapon to burrow into your flesh. You can end the weapon's bond as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, causing the tendrils to retract so you can release the weapon. You can remain attuned to the weapon regardless of whether you're bonded to it. While bonded to it, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Secure Grip
entries: The weapon is bound to your hand and can't be removed from your grasp, voluntarily or involuntarily. If it's a {@itemProperty 2H|XPHB|Two-Handed} weapon, only one of your hands is bound to the weapon.

items.name: Drain Life
entries: When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can choose to expend one {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Die} to deal additional damage with the attack, and as you do, drain the life from your foes. Roll the {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB|Hit Die} and add your Constitution modifier; the attack deals extra Necrotic damage equal to the result, and you regain an equal number of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

magicvariant.name: Byeshk Weapon
entries: Byeshk is a rare and heavy metal of lustrous purple, mined from the Byeshk and Graywall Mountains along Droaam's borders. It can also be found in the Ironlands, a Khyberian demiplane that's been delved into by the Ghaash'kala and Kech Sharaat. Aberrations tied to the daelkyr--including {@creature Dolgaunt|erlw|Dolgaunts}, {@creature Dolgrim|erlw|Dolgrims}, and {@creature mind flayer|XMM|Mind Flayers}--are susceptible to weapons made of byeshk alloys, making the metal highly valued to the Dhakaani, Gatekeepers druids, and others that fight Aberrations. Dhakaani weapons forged during the Xoriat Incursion were often forged from byeshk.

Melee weapons made of or coated with byeshk are not inherently magical weapons, but are unusually effective when used to fight Aberrations. Whenever you hit an Aberration with a byeshk weapon, the Aberration takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the weapon's type, and it can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} until the start of your next turn.
The byeshk version of a Melee weapon costs 400 gp more than the normal version, whether the weapon is made of the metal or coated with it.

Whenever you hit an Aberration with this weapon, the Aberration takes an extra {@damage 1d6} damage of the weapon's type, and it can't regain {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} until the start of your next turn.

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Detection
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Truest Sight
entries: You always have the {@spell True Seeing|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way after you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Finding
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Finder's Focus
entries: You always have the {@spell Commune with Nature|XPHB} and {@spell Find the Path|XPHB} spells prepared. You can cast each spell once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way after you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast these spells using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Handling
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Powerful Influence
entries: You always have the {@spell Dominate Beast|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

In addition, when you cast the {@spell Dominate Beast|XPHB} spell, you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on {@status Concentration|XPHB} checks you make to maintain the spell and you can maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} on the spell for up to 8 hours, as if you had used a level 7 spell slot. You can also maintain the spell while sleeping; if you take damage while sleeping, you must make a {@status Concentration|XPHB} check with {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} to maintain the spell.

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Healing
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Medicine|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Miracle Worker
entries: You always have the {@spell Heal|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Hospitality
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Charisma ({@skill Persuasion|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Home Away From Home
entries: You always have the {@spell Mordenkainen's Magnificent Mansion|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Making
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Master Crafter
entries: You always have the {@spell Fabricate|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells (choose when you receive this gift).

entries.name: Making Friends
entries: You always have the {@spell Create Homunculus|XGE} spell ({@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|XGE}) prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Passage
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Instant Messenger
entries: You always have the {@spell Teleport|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Scribing
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Insight|XPHB}) checks and on ability checks using {@item Calligrapher's Supplies|XPHB}.

entries.name: Symbologist
entries: You always have the {@spell Symbol|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Sentinel
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Sentinel's Shield
entries: You always have the {@spell Globe of Invulnerability|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Shadow
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks.

entries.name: Shadow Weaver
entries: You always have the {@spell Project Image|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Storm
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics|XPHB}) checks and on ability checks made using {@item Navigator's Tools|XPHB}.

entries.name: Storm Caller
entries: You always have the {@spell Control Weather|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

reward.name: Siberys Mark of Warding
entries: You gain the following benefits.

entries.name: Perfect Intuition
entries: You have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) checks and on ability checks using {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}.

entries.name: You Shall Not Pass
entries: You always have the {@spell Forbiddance|XPHB} spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot, and you regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast it using any spell slots you have. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for this spell (choose when you receive this gift).

object.name: Long Rod
entries: A Long Rod is a more portable version of a {@object Siege Staff|ExploringEberron24}, measuring around 8 feet long. Including the stand required to brace it, it weighs close to 350 pounds.

It takes 5 {@action Magic|XPHB} actions to set up a Long Rod, and the same to tear down for transport. Once set up, it takes 1 {@action Magic|XPHB} action to prime the rod, 1 {@action Magic|XPHB} action to aim it, and 1 {@action Magic|XPHB} action to fire it.
Any spell that requires an attack roll or saving throw can be cast through a Long Rod. The range is magnified by a factor of 3, with a long range of up to 6 times the spell's standard range.

The spell's area of effect is increased to 150%. If the spell normally affects a single target, it instead affects a 10-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere}; if the spell normally requires an attack roll, targets must instead make a Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, the target takes half damage and suffers no other effect.

object.name: Siege Staff
entries: {@note Requires Attunement by a Spellcaster}
Siege Staffs, the primary form of arcane artillery, are made of wood—typically around fifteen feet long—engraved with mystic sigils and inlaid with dragonshards.
Activating a Siege Staff takes 3 {@action Magic|XPHB} actions: one to prime the {@item staff|XPHB}; one to aim it; and one to release the spell.
There are several basic models of Siege Staff, each of which serves a different purpose. When activated, it produces one of the following effects, determined by its model:

object.name: Siege Staff (Blast)
entries: {@note Requires Attunement by a Spellcaster}
Siege Staffs, the primary form of arcane artillery, are made of wood—typically around fifteen feet long—engraved with mystic sigils and inlaid with dragonshards.
Activating a Siege Staff takes 3 {@action Magic|XPHB} actions: one to prime the staff; one to aim it; and one to release the spell.

This model was typically used to bombard massed troops or villages, unleashing a wide burst of energy. It has a normal range of 300 feet and a long range of 1,200 feet. It targets all creatures within a 60-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere}. Targets must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 2d8} Force damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.

object.name: Siege Staff (Force)
entries: {@note Requires Attunement by a Spellcaster}
Siege Staffs, the primary form of arcane artillery, are made of wood—typically around fifteen feet long—engraved with mystic sigils and inlaid with dragonshards.
Activating a Siege Staff takes 3 {@action Magic|XPHB} actions: one to prime the staff; one to aim it; and one to release the spell.

This model releases focused blasts of pure energy. Developed late in the war, these were primarily used to target fortifications, warforged titans, and airships. It has a normal range of 600 feet and a long range of 2,400 feet. A target takes 44 ({@damage 8d10}) Force damage.

object.name: Siege Staff (Focus)
entries: {@note Requires Attunement by a Spellcaster}
Siege Staffs, the primary form of arcane artillery, are made of wood—typically around fifteen feet long—engraved with mystic sigils and inlaid with dragonshards.
Activating a Siege Staff takes 3 {@action Magic|XPHB} actions: one to prime the staff; one to aim it; and one to release the spell.

This model amplifies the spells cast by an attuned spellcaster. Any spell that requires an attack roll or saving throw can be cast through this model of Siege Staff. The range is magnified by a factor of 5, with a long range of up to 10 times the spell's standard range—so a {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} cast through a Focus Staff has a normal range of 600 feet and a long range of 1,200 feet. The spell's area of effect is doubled. If the spell normally affects a single target, it instead affects a 20-foot-radius {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere}; if the spell normally requires an attack roll, targets must instead make a Dexterity saving throw. On a successful save, the target takes half damage and suffers no other effect.

itemGroup.name: Tools of the Master
itemGroup.reqAttune: by a Character Proficient with the Tool
entries: While using this tool as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB}, you gain a bonus to spell attack rolls. The bonus is determined by the tool's rarity. In addition, you can add this bonus to any ability check you make using this tool.

itemGroup.name: Dragonmark Channel
itemGroup.reqAttune: by a Creature with a Specific Dragonmark
entries: This brooch is embedded with a small Siberys dragonshard, usually depicting the crest of its dragonmarked house. Each Dragonmark Channel is tied to a specific dragonmark, such as the {@feat Mark of Healing|EFA} or the {@feat Mark of Making|EFA}, and you can only attune to it if you possess that dragonmark.

While wearing a Dragonmark Channel, you can use it to cast any level 1 spell on your Spells of the Mark list. Once you use the channel, it can't be used again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
Your spellcasting ability for this spell is the same as the spellcasting ability for the spells you can cast with your Dragonmark feat.

itemGroup.name: Dragonmark Reservoir
itemGroup.reqAttune: by a Creature with a Specific Dragonmark
entries: Dragonmark Reservoirs are always embedded with a Siberys dragonshard, but come in many forms, most commonly an amulet or bracelet bearing the design of the house crest. Each reservoir is tied to a specific dragonmark, such as the {@feat Mark of Healing|EFA} or the {@feat Mark of Making|EFA}, and you can only attune to it if you possess that dragonmark.

A Dragonmark Reservoir has 7 charges. While wearing it, you can use it to cast any spell on your Spells of the Mark list at 1st or 2nd level, expending a number of charges equal to the level of the spell you cast. The reservoir regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn. Your spellcasting ability for this spell is the same as the spellcasting ability for the spells you can cast with your Dragonmark feat.

itemGroup.name: Channeling Wand
itemGroup.reqAttune: by a Creature with a Specific Dragonmark
entries: This short metal wand is tipped with a Siberys dragonshard. Each Channeling Wand is tied to a specific dragonmark, such as the {@feat Mark of Healing|EFA} or the {@feat Mark of Making|EFA}, and you can only attune to it if you possess that dragonmark.

A Channeling Wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can cast any spell on your Spells of the Mark list, expending a number of charges equal to the level of the spell you cast. Your spellcasting ability for this spell is the same as the spellcasting ability for the other spells you can cast using your Dragonmark feat. You can expend additional charges to enhance the spell, choosing one of the following effects:

items.name: Casting Time
entries: You expend 2 charges to change a spell that normally has a casting time of 1 {@action Magic|XPHB} action to instead be cast as a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}.

items.name: Duration
entries: You expend 1 charge to double the duration of the spell, to a maximum of 24 hours.

items.name: Range
entries: You expend 1 charge to double the range of the spell. If the spell normally has a range of Touch, you can cast it with a range of 30 feet.

items.name: Regaining Charges
entries: The wand regains {@dice 1d6 + 1} expended charges daily at dawn. If you expend the wand's last charge, roll {@dice 1d20}. On a 1, the wand crumbles into ashes and is destroyed.

itemGroup.name: Houseward
entries: {@note Requires the {@feat Mark of Warding|EFA}}

This engraved block of lead, approximately 1 cubic foot in size, holds an embedded Siberys dragonshard. The Houseward provides state-of-the-art magical security, and is typically embedded into the floor of the building it is supposed to protect. If any creature with the {@feat Mark of Warding|EFA} spends 10 minutes touching the Houseward, it can cast {@spell Guards and Wards|XPHB} without requiring Material components.  The area protected by the spell is determined by the rarity of the Houseward. The duration of the spell is 24 days, but the effect ends early if the Houseward is used again to cast the spell, if a creature with the {@feat Mark of Warding|EFA} spends 10 minutes touching the Houseward to end its effects, or if a Houseward is removed from the area it is currently protecting. After being used to cast the spell, the Houseward can't do so again until the next dawn.

item.name: Breath of Siberys
entries: Arcane artillery requires a powerful surge of magical energy to fuel the attack. Wizards and other spellcasters can prime arcane artillery by expending a spell slot, but bombardiers don't have spell slots. Instead, a bombardier charges the weapon by using the Breath of Siberys—a small globe containing a highly refined solution of dragonshards held in a suspended state. While priming arcane artillery, the operator crushes the Breath of Siberys against an engraved brass plate; the sphere dissolves and the weapon is charged.

House Cannith has been developing traditional staffs that can be charged using Breath of Siberys. It takes a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to dissolve the breath on the charging plate, restoring {@dice 1d4} charges to the {@item staff|XPHB}. Cannith artificers are working to adapt other charged items to use Breath of Siberys.

item.name: Battle Rod
entries: The Battle Rod was developed as an alternative to the longer {@item War Staff|ExploringEberron24}, and has gained popularity with wandslingers across Khorvaire. When held in two hands, you can use the rod to cast cantrips at up to twice the standard range. However, when you cast a cantrip beyond the standard range, your attack rolls have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, and targets have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws made against your cantrip. For example, a {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} cast using this rod has a range of 240 feet, but attack rolls against targets more than 120 feet away are made at {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

item.name: Charlatan's Gloves
entries: While wearing these gloves, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to produce an illusory image that fits in the palm of your hand. The image lasts for 1 minute or until your {@status Concentration|XPHB} ends (as if you were {@status Concentration|XPHB|Concentrating} on a spell). The image can't create sound, light, smell, or any other sensory effect. Physical interaction with the image reveals it to be an illusion, because things can pass through it.

If a creature takes a {@action Study|XPHB} action to examine the image, the creature can determine that it is an illusion with a successful Intelligence ({@skill Investigation|XPHB}) check contested by your Charisma ({@skill Deception|XPHB}) check. If a creature discerns the illusion for what it is, the illusion becomes faint to the creature.

item.name: Drybrooch
entries: While holding or wearing this item, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to summon or dismiss a dome of energy that manifests just above your head. This energy repels moderate quantities of {@condition frozen|MonstersOfDrakkenheim} and liquid water, such as rain, snow, bird droppings, or other similar nuisances, but can't be used to protect against harsh environmental hazards or attacks. The energy field is typically silvery and translucent. More expensive models have illusions woven into the field; one popular version creates the image of a sunny blue sky overhead.

item.name: Duster
entries: While holding this wand, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to instantly clean an area within 10 feet of you that is no larger than 1 cubic foot, removing dirt and grime. There are many variations of the Duster; the two-handed Staff of Cleansing covers a five-foot cube with a single {@action Magic|XPHB} action, while the Bright Basin cleans clothing and cloth objects placed within it.

item.name: Integrated Tool
entries: {@note Requires Use by a {@race Warforged|EFA}}

This item attaches to the body of a warforged, and is designed to serve as one of the following tools that weighs 10 pounds or less: an Artisan's Tool, {@item Forgery Kit|XPHB}, {@item Herbalism Kit|XPHB}, {@item Poisoner's Kit|XPHB}, {@item Thieves' Tools|XPHB}, or a {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB}.

You must incorporate the tool into your body before you can use it. Over the course of 1 hour, you can attach the tool or remove it from your body, remaining in contact with it for the whole hour; this can be done over a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

While you're alive, the tool can't be removed from your body against your will. Though the tool has become part of your body, you must still have a hand free to make use of it. You can only have one Integrated Tool attached to your body at a time.

item.name: Lamplighter
entries: While you are holding this wand, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to instantaneously light or snuff out a candle, torch, small campfire, or similar source of flame within 10 feet of you.

item.name: Spark
entries: This small oval stone is engraved with Fernian glyphs. While you are holding the stone, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to touch a candle, torch, small campfire, or similar object, instantly igniting it into flame.

item.name: Talking Wand
entries: While you are holding this wand, your voice and other sounds you produce are three times as loud as normal. House Phiarlan makes use of a similar device, the Thunderous Amulet, that leaves the wearer's hands free.

item.name: Thurimbar Rod
entries: This rod is a magical {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} developed by the gnomes of Zilargo. While holding the rod, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to produce auditory illusions that unerringly replicate the sound of any instrument with which you're proficient, with an effect similar to the {@spell Minor Illusion|XPHB} spell, with the sound emanating from the rod. To determine the quality of the performance, make a Charisma check with the {@item Musical Instrument|XPHB} you're replicating. If you are proficient with the Thurimbar Rod, you can produce unearthly music unlike any natural instrument.

item.name: War Staff
item.reqAttune: by a Spellcaster
entries: Aundair developed this staff to help wandslingers match the range of Thrane archers, but it quickly spread across Khorvaire. While holding this staff in both hands, you can use it as an {@item Arcane Focus|XPHB}. Any cantrip cast using the staff can be cast at up to four times the standard range. However, when you cast a cantrip at more than twice the standard range, your attack rolls have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}, and targets have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws made against your cantrip. For example, a {@spell Fire Bolt|XPHB} cast using this staff has a range of 480 feet, but attack rolls against targets more than 240 feet away are made at {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB}.

item.name: Breastplate of Kamvuul Norek
entries: This adamantine Breastplate of ancient Dhaakan belonged to a hobgoblin hero known as a mighty slayer of Aberrations.

While wearing this armor, you gain a +2 bonus to {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}, any {@variantrule Critical Hit|XPHB} against you becomes a normal hit, and you have {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Additionally, if you succeed on a saving throw against the Mind Blast ability of a Mind Flayer or other Aberration, you are unaffected, and the effect is reflected back toward the Aberration as if the cone originated from you, including the Aberration in its area of effect.

item.name: Ghaal'duur, the Mighty Dirge
item.reqAttune: by a Bard
entries: This three-foot warhorn, a revered artifact of Dhakaan, is carved from the tip of a red dragon's horn, banded with adamantine, and covered with runes of power. An inscription in Goblin reads "A mighty dirge for the fallen foe." Ghaal'duur was crafted by Jhazaal Dhakaan, a legendary dirge singer who united the ancient warring clans. Any kech warlord who obtained it would gain great influence among the Heirs of Dhakaan—and any non-Dhakaani that possesses it bears a dangerous burden.

entries.name: Random Properties
entries: The warhorn has the following random properties (see "Artifacts" in the Dungeon Master's Guide):

items: 2 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Beneficial Properties|XDMG|minor beneficial} properties
1 {@table Artifact Properties; Minor Detrimental Properties|XDMG|minor detrimental} property; any goblinoid attuned to the warhorn is immune to the detrimental effects of this property.

entries.name: Jhazaal's Presence
entries: While you are attuned to the warhorn, your Charisma increases by 4, to a maximum of 24.

entries.name: The Dragon's Song
entries: When holding the warhorn in both hands, you can use it as a {@variantrule Spellcasting Focus|XPHB} for your Bard spells. Bard spells cast using the warhorn gain the following benefits:

items: If the spell has a duration of 1 minute or longer, its duration is doubled, to a maximum duration of 24 hours.
If the spell has a range of 5 feet or greater, its range is doubled.
If the spell is 1st level or higher, it is cast as if from a spell slot 1 level higher than the spell slot you expended.

entries.name: The Sound of Victory
entries: While holding the warhorn in both hands, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to blow it, empowering your allies and intimidating your foes. For the next 10 minutes, any time an ally within 600 feet of you that can hear you makes an attack roll or a saving throw, it adds {@dice 1d4} to the attack roll or save. If the creature is a goblinoid, it adds {@dice 2d4} instead of {@dice 1d4}. Additionally, every enemy within 600 feet of you that can hear you must make a Charisma saving throw against your Bard spell save DC. For the next 10 minutes, whenever a target that fails this save makes an attack roll or a saving throw before the spell ends, the target must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the attack roll or save. If the target is a goblinoid, it subtracts {@dice 2d4} instead of {@dice 1d4}.
Once you use this property, you can't do so again until you finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries.name: Destroying the Horn
entries: It's said that only the fire of Jharaashta, the dragon who sacrificed his horn for its creation, can destroy the horn. But after nine thousand years, most sages assume that the mighty dragon is long dead.

item.name: Grieving Tree
item.reqAttune: Using Lost Techniques
entries: A Grieving Tree is a giant skeletal tree made of the purest white marble, weighing thousands of pounds. One of the greatest inventions of the daashor Taruuzh, a Grieving Tree is part execution device and part torture device; a nearly inescapable prison that sustains victims on the very edge of death. The secrets to the tree's construction were lost with Taruuzh's death, as was the art of controlling them. To attune to a Grieving Tree, a character will have to rediscover these forgotten techniques.

entries.name: Lingering Life
entries: The tree has a pool of {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. The pool starts at 20 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, and gains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} whenever the tree uses its Eviscerate ability, to a maximum of 200 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. As long as there are {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} in this pool, whenever an imprisoned creature drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} but is still alive, that creature is healed {@dice 1d4 + 1} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} and the same amount is subtracted from the pool.

entries.name: Prisoners of the Tree
entries: The tree can hold up to four creatures (or their corpses) at a time. A creature that is within 5 feet of a prisoner can attempt to free it from the tree by making a DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics|XPHB}) check. On a success, the prisoner is freed, and both creatures take {@damage 3d6} Piercing damage. On a failure, the prisoner remains in the tree, and both creatures take the Piercing damage.

entries.name: Tree Control
entries: While attuned to the tree and within 120 feet of it, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Grab
entries: You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to target a creature within 20 feet of the tree. The target must make a DC 24 Dexterity saving throw as the tree reaches down to snare them. On a failed save, the tree captures the target within its branches. The target takes {@damage 6d6} Piercing damage, and has the {@condition Stunned|XPHB} condition until it's released from the tree.

items.name: Eviscerate
entries: You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to command the tree to eviscerate its unfortunate prisoners, draining their life and blood as the branches shake and quiver. All creatures {@condition Stunned|XPHB} by the tree take {@damage 8d6} Piercing damage, and half of the total damage dealt is added to the tree's Lingering Life pool.

items.name: Answer for Their Crimes
entries: You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to cast {@spell Speak with Dead|XPHB} on the corpse of a creature imprisoned in the tree, without expending a spell slot or requiring Material components. When you cast the spell in this manner, the corpse is compelled to speak truthfully.

items.name: Release a Prisoner
entries: You can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to command the tree to release one of its prisoners.

item.name: Keeper's Fang
entries: These infamous weapons, prized by assassins, have a Khyber dragonshard embedded into the pommel that channels the souls of victims, but doesn't itself trap them. There's much debate over the actual fate of the souls of those slain by a Keeper's Fang. Common myth says that the souls of victims are trapped in the Lair of the Keeper, and heroes can seek to reclaim a soul from the Sovereign of Death and Decay. Another myth maintains that these weapons channel souls to the overlord Katashka, and that one must deal with the Lords of Dust to restore a victim. Most Keeper's Fangs were created by the Shaarat'khesh assassins of the Empire of Dhakaan. Rather than ascribing the blade's power to the Keeper--whose existence the Dhakaani reject--they believe these blades utterly destroy the souls of their victims.

You gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. Whenever you use it to reduce a creature to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, the creature is slain and its soul removed. A creature whose soul has been stolen in this way can be restored to life only by means of a {@spell Wish|XPHB} spell.

item.name: Shaarat'doovol, the Blade of Truth
entries: This blade was forged in khaar'draguus, the lava pits below Sharn, and wielded by an ancient Dhakaani hero who fell in battle against the daelkyr Belashyrra. A sentience lies within the blade; it doesn't communicate with words, but while attuned, you can feel its emotions and desires. Shaarat'doovol was forged to protect the innocent from the machinations of the daelkyr, and if it feels you are serving that purpose, it can grant great power.
You gain a +3 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon. When you hit an Aberration with this weapon, the Aberration takes an extra {@damage 2d10} Radiant damage.

entries.name: Unyielding Duty
entries: If you have the favor of the sword, it guides you and shields you from unnatural influences. While wielding this sword, it can choose to grant you the following benefits:

items.name: Truesight
entries: You gain {@sense Truesight|XPHB} with a range of 90 feet.

items.name: Fortified Mind
entries: You have {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB} to the {@condition Charmed|XPHB} and {@condition Frightened|XPHB} conditions and {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB} to Psychic damage.

item.name: Uul'kur (Dream Key)
entries: This iron token is inlaid with a sliver of a Siberys dragonshard. Most are worn as brooches, but others take the form of coins or keys. While an Uul'kur is a Common magic item, the secret of their creation is known only to the chot'uul monks of the Heirs of Dhakaan, and they are largely unknown in the Five Nations.

When you sleep with an Uul'kur on your person, you remain fully lucid when you dream, and when you wake, you clearly remember everything that transpired. If you understand the workings of the Uul'kur, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to bind it to your dreams until the next dawn. While bound, any creature who sleeps with this token on its person shares your dream instead of creating its own, provided you are asleep at the same time.

item.name: Vola'khesh
entries: This small carved stone is typically bound to a leather strap worn around the wrist or neck. Designed by the Dhakaani duur'kala, the Vola'khesh facilitates communication between elite units. They are created in linked sets; up to ten stones can be bound together, and once established, this link cannot be changed. At present, the Vola'khesh are only used by the Kech Dhakaan and are unknown to the people of the Five Nations. If the enchantments were replicated, these tools could be put into use by spies and law enforcement agencies of the Five Nations.

While wearing a Vola'khesh, you can take a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB} to whisper a message. This message is heard by all creatures within 120 feet wearing a linked Vola'khesh. Magical silence, 1 foot of stone, 1 inch of common metal, or 3 feet of wood will block this effect, but the magic doesn't have to follow a straight line and can travel freely around corners or through openings.

item.name: Detection Channeling Wand
item.reqAttune: by a Creature with the Mark of Detection
entries: This short metal wand is tipped with a Siberys dragonshard.

A Channeling Wand has 7 charges. While holding it, you can cast any spell on your {@feat Mark of Detection|EFA|Spells of the Mark} list, expending a number of charges equal to the level of the spell you cast. Your spellcasting ability for this spell is the same as the spellcasting ability for the other spells you can cast using your Dragonmark feat.
